utterances: Right.
…but a lot of critics say, hey, you might want to take a second look.
And yeah, and again, perfect time for that.
I don't consider myself a diehard science fiction fan, so I'm always lobbied by those fans when they want me to watch something on SciFi Channel.
But I came to ""Battlestar Gallactica"" late and you don't have to be a sci-fi fan to really appreciate what a great series it is, and now is a good time.
There's a lot of - there's episodes to catch up on, a couple of seasons worth of material.
And I think people will really be drawn in to the storytelling.
And part of it - and part of the reason it's so good - and John Landgraf, who runs FX, told me this quote one time, he said, if they had a million more dollars, it would be terrible.
And so they couldn't do special effects and they had to do character-driven series - stories and that's why it's so good.
We're talking with Tim Goodman, a TV critic with the San Francisco Chronicle, about what reruns we'd like to see while the writers are on strike.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.

I think - and I've tried to encourage people to, like, experiment with something whether you're renting it or buying it that you've never seen before.
And one of the ones, Neal, that I've recommended for years - and people when they discover it, the feedback I get from them is more than any other show.
And it's a Canadian - it's a really, really sweet Canadian series called ""Slings and Arrows."" And people who discover ""Slings and Arrows"" as a comedy/drama are - they're just changed.

This is a really great television.
